# Foreign venture capitalists and the internationalization of entrepreneurial companies: Evidence from China # Mark Humphery-Jenner and Jo-Ann Suchard1 Australian School of Business, University of New South Wales, Sydney, Australia Correspondence: M Humphery-Jenner, Room 350, Australian School of Business, University of New South Wales, Sydney NsW 2052, Australia. Tel: + 61 29 385 1000; Fax: $^+$ 6129 385 6347; ## Abstract We use a comprehensive database of venture-capital-backed companies from China to test whether and how foreign venture capitalists (VCs) can facilitate international initial public offerings of entrepreneurial companies. Foreign VCs increase the likelihood that a portfolio company will list on a foreign exchange and use a top lawyer, banker, or accountant when doing so. The propensity to list overseas is moderated by the number of venture backers, the fund's size, and governance in the domestic market. Foreign VCs encourage foreign listings in domestic-backed companies. We take steps to address sample selection and endogeneity concerns. Overall, we show that foreign VCs encourage internationalization in entrepreneurial companies. ournal of International Business Studies (2013) 44, 607-621. doi:10.1057/jibs.2013.2 Keywords: venture capital; private equity and portfolio diversification; China; crossborder investments; internationalization; initial public offerings (IPOs) ## INTRODUCTION The last decade has seen an increase in international participation in venture investments and the globalization of venture capital (e.g., Guler & Guillen, 2010). A sizable portion of this capital has flowed to emerging markets (Chakma, Sammut, & Agrawal, 2013), notwithstanding evidence that the poor-governance environments characteristic of such markets tend to affect venture capital outcomes negatively. While it is arguable that geographic distance might make it difficult for venture capitalists (VCs) to monitor and mentor portfolio companies (Humphery-Jenner & Suchard, 2013; Lutz, Bender, Achleitner, & Kaserer, 2012), foreign VCs sometimes try to justify their presence by arguing that they can facilitate internationalization by enabling portfolio companies to list on foreign exchanges. The purpose of this paper is to test the claim that foreign VCs can indeed facilitate internationalization of portfolio companies. Listing on a foreign exchange can be an important strategic decision for a firm, potentially providing access to overseas customers and additional capital (Moore, Bell, Filatotchev, & Rasheed, 2012). Less mature firms (such as start-ups) might have difficulties listing on foreign exchanges, owing to problems of information asymmetry and home asset bias (Bell, Filatotchev, & Rasheed, 2012; Caglio, Hanley, & MariettaWestberg, 2011), problems likely to be especially severe for companies in developing markets attempting to list in developed markets (Moore, Bell, & Filatotchev, 2010). Foreign VCs (i.e.,VCs that operate across borders) could help to overcome information asymmetries, as foreign institutional investors are often associated with the transmission of improved corporate governance (Aggarwal, Erel, Ferreira, & Matos, 2011). In addition, foreign VCs are typically larger, better connected with key intermediaries, more experienced, and more knowledgeable than are domestic VCs about international (developed) markets. There is a dearth of comprehensive evidence about whether, or how, foreign VCs can facilitate the internationalization of their portfolio companies. While Hursti and Maula (2007) suggest that foreign VCs can help European companies list overseas, there is little comparable evidence for emerging markets. Khoury, Junkunc, and Mingo (2012) use data from 433 VC transaction rounds in 13 Latin American countries to examine how sovereign governance influences $\mathrm{VC}s^{\prime}$ investment practices. Lerner and Schoar (2005) use a sample of 210 PE-backed companies to highlight the fact that legal enforcement affects PE transactions. Ahlstrom and Bruton (2006) and Bruton and Ahlstrom (2003) support this claim with interview-based evidence. Wang and Wang (2011) and Dai, Jo, and Kassicieh (2011) examine investments in 243 and 418 portfolio companies in China, respectively. These, however, are relatively small samples, in view of the 4753 Chinese venture-backed companies that we have identified. Such small samples raise concerns about sample selection, and restrict the depth of analysis of the activities of foreign VCs. Wang and Wang (2012) seek to address the sample-size issue by examining a sample of 6025 VC investments across 35 countries. However, using a multi-country sample can incur the cost of introducing another source of variance for which a study must control. These studies also do not examine the role of foreign VCs in facilitating internationalization. We overcome the small-sample problem by examining a large sample of Chinese portfolio companies that received VC investments between 1988 and 2011 (sourced from ChinaVenture). China is an ideal market in which to test the contribution of foreign VCs to internationalization, for several reasons. First, it has attracted a significant amount of foreign VC capital, with VC investment rising from ${\mathrm{US}}\$1.2$ billion in 1999 to US\$31.4 billion in 2010 Jiang, Cai, Keasey, & Wright, 2011). Second, the Chinese government has instituted significant changes in the regulation of mergers and acquisitions (M&As) and initial public offerings (IPOs) (Huang, 2008, 2011). This enables us to examine how the likelihood of foreign listing is affected by the quality of sovereign governance. Third, China is a market with relatively nascent domestic capital markets and haphazard regulations. This allows us to examine how sovereign governance modifies the propensity to pursue an international listing. We start with a comprehensive sample of 4753 portfolio companies that have received VC backing. To examine our central hypotheses, we focus on a subsample of 677 companies that have been successfully exited via an IPO. We use this sample of 677 companies to investigate whether foreign VCs can facilitate internationalization in the form of listing on foreign exchanges. We arrive at several key findings that contribute to the literature. First, we show that foreign VCs significantly increase the likelihood that a portfolio company will list on a foreign exchange. This indicates that foreign VCs do indeed contribute to the internationalization of portfolio companies. Second, we show that regulatory and commercial changes influence the propensity to pursue international IPOs. Third, we find that the presence of a foreign VC increases the likelihood that a domestic-backed company will list overseas. This suggests that some syndicate diversity can be beneficial in achieving particular outcomes. We also find the related result that the impact of foreign VCs on internationalization is moderated by the total number of VCs who invest in the portfolio company. Fourth, we find that companies backed by foreign VCs are significantly more likely to use top-tier lawyers, investment banks, and accountants, suggesting that such connections might be one mechanism through which foreign VCs can facilitate international listings. These results contribute to a burgeoning stream of literature that aims to examine precisely “how" VCs contribute value to portfolio companies (e.g., Harford & Kolasinski, 2012; Hochberg, 2012). The results also contribute to the literature on the importance of connections within the VC/PE industry (Hochberg, Ljungqvist, & Lu, 2007, 2010). Specifically, our results support the idea that foreign VCs can add value through their choice of partners in the IPO exit process. THEORYDEVELOPMENTANDHYPOTHESES The goal of this paper is to examine the role of foreign VCs in the internationalization of portfolio companies, with a specific focus on how foreign VCs can facilitate IPOs in international markets. ### Overseas Funds and IPO Location Entrepreneurial companies often face barriers to operating abroad. Apart from market-driven economic costs, firms incur social costs of access and acceptance when attempting to do business in a foreign country, costs often referred to as the "liability of foreignness" (Mata & Freitas, 2012; Zaheer, 1995). For entrepreneurial companies, the liability of foreignness is compounded by the liability of newness (Certo, 2003). Together, such factors mean that entrepreneurial companies face barriers in raising capital in developed markets (Bell et al., 2012; Caglio et al., 2011). Such problems could be especially severe for companies in information-poor environments that attempt to list overseas (Moore et al., 2010). Given that potential issuers are aware of the liabilities of foreignness and of newness, their efforts will focus on overcoming these liabilities to make their IPO a success (Moore et al., 2012). Foreign VC funds are likely to be better placed than domestic VC funds to facilitate internationalization. If a portfolio company is exited via an IPO, it can list on a domestic or an overseas market. Listing on an overseas market is easier if the portfolio company has better access to experts in that market and/or has the financial backing of a sponsor who can navigate the international listing process. Foreign VCs are more likely than domestic VCs to have such connections. In addition, funds that make cross-border investments tend to be comparatively large and well resourced (Wang & Wang, 2012), and foreign VCs are more likely than domestic VCs to have institutional knowledge about foreign markets. For example, a US-based VC, with experience in the United States, is more likely to have institutional knowledge of the US market than is a VC based in China. Additionally, foreign VCs may have a greater incentive to list companies in a developed market such as the United States (aside from the significant barriers to listing companies in China and repatriating profits). Developed markets are typically well established, and have strong regulations. This is important for post-IPO value-adding activity and capital raising. It is also important for a VC that wishes to distribute its shares to its investors (limited partners) at the end of the lock-up period. Thus, we expect that foreign-backed portfolio companies are more likely than domestic-backed portfolio companies to do an IPO in a foreign market Hypothesis 1: If a Chinese VC investment is to undertake an IPO, then a foreign-backed investment is more likely to undertake the IPO in an exchange outside of China. ### Moderating Effects ### Sovereign governance Foreign funds have several advantages in listing overseas, although their inclination to do so is likely to be influenced by the quality of regulations and governance in the domestic market. VCs want to at least recoup the money they invested (preferably maximizing their returns on investments). Poorly regulated markets will be less efficient, and companies that list in such markets risk trading at a discount, owing to the illiquidity, poor market quality, and opacity that can result from inadequate regulations. Further, if the post-IPO price is below the firm's fundamental value (possibly due to opacity associated with a paucity of market regulation), then the backer might suffer a reputational penalty for failure to obtain an adequate price for the company. To the extent that foreign VCs are sensitive to this risk, they are more likely to encourage their portfolio company to list in a developed market with strong regulations. China's securities markets appear to suffer from these problems, as reflected by the concerns raised about its securities laws/regulations (e.g., Chen, Firth, & Gao, 2005) and the enforcement thereof (He & Su, 2013; Humphery-Jenner, 2013). However, the quality of China's financial markets has improved over time. In particular, China's regulation of markets has improved through increasingly strong restrictions on market manipulation and accounting misstatements (Huang, 2007; Jia, Ding, Li, & Wu, 2009), a trend that may make China's financial markets more attractive, increasing the likelihood of domestic IPO exits. This background suggests that while foreign VCs will remain more likely to IPO a company overseas, their willingness to list a company in Mainland China will increase with improvements in China's regulation and governance. Hypothesis 2: While foreign-backed Chinese companies remain more likely to list IPOs overseas, the proportion of such IPO listings that occur in Mainland China increases with the strength of regulation/governance in Mainland China. ### Foreign VCs in domestic-backed companies The involvement of foreign VCs affects the propensity of domestic VCs to list their portfolio firms in their home market. The greater a domestic VC's institutional knowledge and expertise are in the home market, the more likely it is to list a company domestically. A foreign VC can provide outside/ foreign institutional knowledge and connections to a company backed by domestic VCs. Thus, the presence of a foreign VC could increase the propensity to internationalize a domestically backed company. This logic has the natural corollary that VC-syndicate diversity can help achieve outcomes such as internationalization. We capture this in the following hypothesis. Hypothesis 3: The presence of a foreign VC moderates the impact of domestic backing on the likelihood of overseas listing. In particular, the presence of a foreign VC increases the likelihood that a domestically backed company will list overseas. #### Other characteristics Several factors might moderate the impact of foreign VCs on the likelihood of an overseas listing. Larger funds, for example, are likely to be better resourced and have more connections and potentially more experience than smaller funds. Thus, we expect the effect of the presence of foreign VCs on the likelihood of foreign listing to increase with fund size. While some large companies do benefit from cross-listing, and are generally more likely than smaller companies to cross-list (Pagano, Roell, & Zechner, 2002), in the VC market overseas listings tend to have a greater benefit for smaller entrepreneurial companies that will benefit more from increased access to capital, and from the “bonding" benefits of listing in a developed market. Finally, portfolio companies that have the backing of many VCs are more likely to list overseas than companies with fewer VCs, because having a larger number of backers provides access to a larger number of intermediaries and financiers, who can help facilitate an international listing. We capture these expectations in the following hypothesis. Hypothesis 4: The impact of foreign VCs on the likelihood of an international IPO increases with fund size, and with the number of investors in a company, but decreases with company size. ### Overseas Funds and Top Lawyers, Accountants, and Bankers Next, we examine some of the mechanisms through which foreign VCs might enhance internationalization. One of these is that foreign VCs can leverage their networks of financial institutions to facilitate international listings. This potential advantage follows from prior literature showing $\mathrm{VC}s^{\prime}$ connections to be an important driver of value-creation in VC deals (Hochberg et al., 2007, 2010). Such connections include links to top-tier bankers, toptier lawyers, and top-tier accountants that could be developed through repeat interactions (Cao & Liu, 2012; Huang, Shangguan, & Zhang, 2008). There is evidence of improved M&A outcomes from using top-tier lawyers (Karsten, 2012), investment banks (Bao & Edmans, 2011), and law firms (Krishnan, Masulis, Thomas, & Thompson, 2012; Krishnan & Masulis, forthcoming). Further, there is evidence that top-tier banks tend to convey additional benefits in the form of higher certification (Lee & Wahal, 2004), higher-quality post-IPO research coverage (Fang & Yasuda, 2010), and a larger clientele of institutional investors who can monitor the firm (Woidtke, 2002). Top-tier accountants could ameliorate governance issues within portfolio companies - issues that could be especially prevalent in emerging markets - and could provide certification benefits during the exit/IPO processes. International VCs are more likely to be sophisticated investors, with more connections to major international firms (Hochberg et al., 2007), and thus are more likely to have access to top lawyers, bankers, and accountants. This leads to the following hypothesis: Hypothesis 5: Foreign VC involvement increases the likelihood of using top-tier lawyers, top-tier accountants, and top-tier bankers during the IPO process. ## DATAANDSAMPLEDESCRIPTION Our data are sourced from ChinaVenture, and include information on portfolio companies and the funds or general partners (GPs) that invest in the companies. We start with 4753 portfolio companies that received investments between 1988 and 2011 (for which ChinaVenture also has control variables, indicated below). We then restrict our sample to 677 companies that were exited via IPO (as our goal is to examine the role of foreign VCs in international listings). In our data set, each portfolio company counts as one observation: the unit of analysis is thus the individual portfolio company. We use these data to analyze the types of companies in which overseas VC/PE funds invest, and the types of exits that they are most likely to use. Our sample allows us to define the following variables (all are from ChinaVenture unless otherwise indicated), summarized in Table 1. ### Foreign-Backing Variables A fund is defined as “overseas" (interchangeably: foreign) if it derives its funding from overseas. A fund is defined as a ${}^{\prime\prime}\mathrm{JV}^{\prime\prime}$ if it derives its funding from both foreign and domestic sources. This enables us to examine the importance of a foreign fund co-investing with a domestic fund. We code our dependent variables as follows: I (At least one foreign VC) equals 1 if at least one of its VC backers derives its financing from overseas. I (At least one foreign/Jv VC) equals 1 if at least one of its VC backers derives its financing either (a) purely overseas or (b) both overseas and domestically. We also collect data on the proportion of backers that are foreign or JVs. These data are collected for each round of investment, and for the overall company. Table 1 Variable definitions

### Exit Variables We specify variables that indicate whether an IPO exit is on a foreign market, and each country in which an IPO exit occurs. The data also indicate whether a given VC-backed company is exited via an M&A, a secondary buyout, or an IPO (or is not yet exited). We do not focus on M&As or secondary buyouts, as these exit types are not core to the analysis. There may also be some under-reporting of M&As and secondary buyouts, as we have 677 IPO exits compared with only 189 M&A exits and 31 secondary buyout exits (which contrasts to US evidence,in Harford & Kolasinski,2012，where only a minority of VC-backed companies are exited via IPO). We make no claims about whether the deals “not yet exited" are liquidations. This is because some will be liquidations and some will merely be companies that have not sufficiently matured, and VCs have an incentive to conceal (and thus not report) failed investments, which makes it difficult to determine why a company is not yet exited. ### Governance Variables Hypothesis 2 suggests that the likelihood of an IPO in Mainland China increases with the strength of governance in China. There are myriad potential governance variables. Given that we are interested in assessing changes in governance over time, we use the S&P sovereign risk rating. The S&P rating is time varying (cf. the anti-director rights index in La Porta, Lopez-de-Silanes, Shleifer, & Vishny, 1997, 1998, and later modified in Spamann, 2010). The rating ranges from 0 to 20 (although, in our sample, China's S&P score ranges from 12 to 16). A higher score connotes better sovereign governance. ### Other Independent Variables We control for various other variables that might influence the likelihood of foreign investment and/or exit outcomes. We group these into several categories. The first group includes characteristics of the portfolio company. ChinaVenture reports the industry in which the company operates. These industry classifications are analogous to four-digit SIC industry classifications. To examine the industries on which foreign VCs focus, we condense these into industry dummies that are analogous to two-digit SIC industries. In addition, ChinaVenture includes information on the province in which a company is based. This enables us to create region indicators to examine the geographic preferences of foreign VC funds. The second group includes investment information such as investment stage (i.e., start-up, development, or late stage). Larger international funds might focus on purchasing larger (i.e., late-stage) investments, owing to difficulties in monitoring smaller companies in poor-governance countries (Zhou & Xu, 2012). Further, whether a company is a start-up or a late-stage investment might influence exit mechanisms, owing to China's relatively stringent requirements for a company to IPO. Additional variables include the number of rounds of financing, the total number of investors, and the total disclosed stake that VCs have in the company. Third, we construct variables to proxy for $\mathrm{VC}s^{\prime}$ level of experience and success. Although we cannot directly identify the “lead" VC in a company, we proxy for the lead VC by taking the maximum of several characteristics across the set of VCs that invest in the company. These include the maximum number of (prior) exits that any VC has achieved (to proxy for VC experience), the maximum number of investments that any VC investor has achieved, the maximum number of regions in which any VC investor has invested, and the maximum number of industries in which any VC has invested. The multivariate models also control for year, industry and subnational-region (i.e., province) fixed effects (in light of prior evidence of strong time/ industry effects; Johnson, Moorman, & Sorescu, 2009; Petersen, 2009), and sub-national region effects (Ma, Tong, & Fitza, 2013). There are some significant differences in the portfolio companies across IPO exit location. Table 2 contains the univariate statistics by IPO exit location. The proportion of portfolio companies with a foreign backer is significantly higher for companies that list either in Hong Kong or overseas. Further, companies that list overseas tend to be backed by VC funds that are larger and more experienced, as proxied by the amount of investments and exits made by the companies' VC backers. Of the companies that list overseas, a larger proportion of companies are start-ups ( $14\%$ of VC-backed companies that list overseas are start-ups, compared with $5.6\%$ of companies that pursue a mainland listing). This supports the idea that China's listing requirements tend to be less accommodating to start-ups than those in other countries. Table 2 Summary statistics by listing location

This table contains the proportion of overseas-backed and non-overseas-backed companies that IPO in diferent regions. ## RESULTS ### Foreign VCs, Overseas Listings, and Moderating Factors This section contains univariate statistics and multivariate models used to test Hypotheses 1-4. We hypothesize that overseas VC backers are more likely to exit companies overseas (i.e., outside Mainland China), and that this tendency is modified by higher-quality governance in the domestic market (i.e., China). We anticipate that the presence of a foreign VC will moderate the likelihood that a domestic-backed company will IPO in Mainland China. In addition, we expect that factors such as fund size will moderate the propensity for foreign VCs to IPO a company overseas. The univariate statistics indicate that foreignbacked companies are more likely to list overseas. The statistics on IPO exit locations are presented in Table 3. Of the companies with a foreign VC backer, only $20\%$ list in Mainland China. By contrast, $88.8\%$ of firms without a foreign VC backer list on a Mainland Chinese market. The multivariate results support the idea that foreign VCs are less likely than domestic VCs to pursue IPOs in Mainland China. This table containslogitmodels that predict thelocationof IOsThe sample comprisesnly thoseVC-backed companiesthat exit viaanIO.Table1 containsthevariabledefinitions.Themodels i Columns 1-3and 6-9are logit modelsthat include year dummies, regiondummies, and industry dummies and use robust standard errors. The models in Columns 4 and 5 mit the year dummis. as these become collinear with the S&P rating variable. Parentheses contain $p$ -values, and $\star,\star\star$ . and \*\*\* denote significance at $10\%$ $5\%,$ and $1\%,$ respectively. Columns 1, 2, and 3 examine the impact of foreign backing per se. Both the variables I (At least one foreign VC) and I (At least one foreign/JV VC) significantly reduce the likelihood of listing in Mainland China. These results support Hypothesis 1 (namely, that if the investment is exited via IPO, then foreign VCs are more likely to IPO in a market outside Mainland China). The results also support the idea that the likelihood of foreign listing varies with the quality of governance in the domestic market (consistent with Hypothesis 2). Columns 4 and 5 show interactions between the foreign VC backing variables and the sovereign governance variable (S&P Rating). The foreign-backing terms remain independently significant and negative in both models, confirming that foreign backing reduces the likelihood of mainland listing. However, the interaction terms (i.e., I (At least one Foreign $\mathrm{VC})\times\mathrm{S\&P}$ Rating) are positive and weakly significant, suggesting that improvements in governance moderate the likelihood of overseas listing by foreign backers. We find some evidence that the presence of foreign VCs increases the likelihood that a company backed by domestic VCs will list overseas (supporting Hypothesis 3). Column 6 examines the role of domestic and foreign VCs, independently of other factors. Column 7 examines how the presence of a foreign VC moderates the likelihood that a domestic-backed company will list overseas. The interaction term I (At least one Foreign $\mathrm{VC})\times\mathrm{I}$ (At least one Domestic VC) in Column 7 is significant and negative. This implies that the presence of a foreign VC significantly reduces the likelihood that a domestic-backed company will list on a Mainland Chinese market. That is, the presence of foreign VCs contributes to the internationalization of domestic-backed companies. These results support Hypothesis 3. Our results also suggest that some factors moderate the impact of foreign VCs on internationalization. The relevant results are presented in Column 8 of Table 4. The larger the number of foreign VCs, the more likely a firm is to list overseas, consistent with the idea that increased connections, due to the increased number of backers, help to facilitate international listings. Conversely, the larger the investments made by foreign funds, the less likely the backers are to IPO the company overseas, consistent with the idea that smaller companies have more difficulty satisfying the listing requirements of Chinese financial markets - requirements that have historically favored large, established companies. Examples of such requirements include the requirement that a listed company can “make profits continuously" (Securities Law Article 13(2)) and the RMB $30\mathrm{m}$ capitalization requirement (Securities Law Article 50(2)). ### Are Foreign VCs More Likely to Make Use of Top-Tier Lawyers, Accountants, and Bankers? We next address one of the mechanisms through which foreign VCs might achieve internationalization benefits: the use of a top-tier banker, lawyer, or accountant. We examine the use of top-tier accountants and lawyers by examining whether one of the Big 4 accounting firms, one of the top 25 international law firms, or one of the top international investment banks is involved in the IPO process. We define these in Table 1. The results are presented in Table 5. The results show that foreign VCs significantly increase the likelihood of using a top lawyer, banker, or accountant, as indicated by the positive, and significant, coefficients on the variables I (At least one foreign VC) and I (At least one foreign/JV VC). This implies that one avenue through which foreign VCs can create value for portfolio firms is by using their connections with other financial intermediaries, potentially establishing certification benefits during the IPO. ### Additional Robustness Tests #### General robustness tests First, we ensure that the results are robust to various fixed effects. The main models used in our analysis are year dummies, industry dummies, and region dummies. For those models that do not rely on dummies in the analysis of regions or industries, we check robustness. We find that the results are qualitatively the same if we replace the industry dummies by broader industry sector dummies (used to examine the regional preferences of foreign VC funds). Our results are also robust to excluding the dummies. The results are qualitatively the same if we cluster standard errors by industry, year, and/or province. We also cluster standard errors by the lead fund, which we define as the fund that invests the most money in the company. The results are also robust to exclusion of deals that occurred before 2000 (before which our sample contains relatively few deals). #### Selection issues The results are robust to controlling for nonrandomness in the companies that receive foreign Table 5 Logit models predicting use of top accountants, lawyers, and bankers

This table presents logit models that predict the use of a Big 4 accountant, a top 25 lawyer, or a top investment bank (IB). The column title contains tht dependent variable. The models are logit models that include year dummies, region dummies, and industry dummies, and use robust standard errors Parentheses contain $p$ -values, and $^{\star},^{\star\star},$ : and \*\* denote significance at $10\%$ $5\%$ and $1\%,$ respectively. VC backing. We address concerns about systematic differences between foreign-backed and non-foreign-backed companies in two ways. First, we use a weighting approach (following Busso et al., 2011). We estimate a first-stage probability that a firm will receive foreign VC backing (or foreign/JV backing) as a function of the variables Num Rounds, Total Num Investors, ln (Total Invested Amount), I (Start-up), I (Late), and Total Disclosed Stake. Next, we calculate a weighting score, defined as $$ \begin{array}{r l}{{\mathrm{Weight}=\mathrm{I}(\mathrm{Overseas~VC~Backing})}}&{{}}\ {{\displaystyle~+\left[1-\mathrm{I}(\mathrm{Overseas~VC~Backing})\right]}}&{{}}\ {{\displaystyle~\times\frac{\mathrm{Prob}(\mathrm{Overseas~VC~Backing})}{1-\mathrm{Prob}(\mathrm{Overseas~VC~Backing})}}}\end{array} $$ where Prob (Overseas VC Backing) refers to the propensity score obtained from the first-stage regression. Then, for all the models that are not restricted to the subsample of overseas-backed companies, we weight the covariance matrix using this weighting factor. The results (unreported for brevity) are qualitatively the same in these models. Second, we use a propensity score approach. We use the above-mentioned first-stage regression to calculate the probability that a firm will receive overseas VC backing. For the set of firms that do receive foreign VC backing, we compute a range of propensity scores, and identify the propensity scores that mark the $10\%$ lower tail of this distribution. Then, for the companies that do not receive overseas backing, we omit all companies whose propensity scores are below the $10\%$ cut-off. The idea is to remove all firms whose characteristics render them unlikely to receive foreign VC backing. The results (unreported for brevity) are robust to omission of these firms from the sample. ### Endogeneity issues: Subsample regressions Endogeneity is a key concern in international business research (Reeb, Sakakibara, & Mahmood, 2012). One concern is that the possibility of an international exit may cause the foreign VC to invest (rather than the foreign VC causing the firm to undertake an international exit). One way to address endogeneity issues is to examine subsamples in which endogeneity is less likely to hold. The subsample results are qualitatively similar to the reported results, and are unreported for brevity. The subsamples are as follows. First, we examine size-based subsamples. Endogeneity might be less likely to hold for the set of small portfolio companies. This is because the small portfolio companies might not have the management expertise or capital necessary to undertake an international listing (without the help of a VC backer). Consequently, we divide the sample into halves based upon how much capital the portfolio company received. Second, we examine investment-time subsamples. If the mere prospect of an international exit attracted the foreign VC, then we would expect the foreign VC to invest for a relatively short period of time. Thus, endogeneity is less likely to hold for the set of portfolio companies that received foreign VC backing a significant time prior to exit. We therefore examine the subsample of companies where the foreign VC backer invested at least 500 days before the IPO (or, more stringently, 750 days before the IPO). We also examine the subsample of companies in which the foreign VC invested in the first round of VC investment. #### Endogeneity issues: Two-stage regressions We also use a two-stage regression approach to address endogeneity concerns. For both I (At least one Foreign VC) and I (At least one Foreign/JV VC), we generate two instruments: the proportion of all portfolio companies that receive foreign VC backing (or foreign/JV VC backing, as appropriate) in (1) the subject company's year of first investment and industry, and (2) the subject company's year of first investment and region/province. These instruments should satisfy the exclusion restriction, because there is no per se reason to believe that a large foreign VC presence in a particular region or industry will necessarily make any one company more likely to list overseas. The instruments should satisfy the relevance requirement, because a large foreign VC presence in a particular region (or industry) is likely to encourage further foreign VC investment in companies in that region or industry. We statistically verify the validity of the instruments. The results for the second stage of the regressions, suppressed for brevity, are available on request, but are consistent with the main reported models. #### Endogeneity issues: Portfolio company quality We also address the possibility that foreign VCs will focus on high-quality companies that are more likely to achieve a successful IPO exit by virtue of being high quality, rather than because of the presence of a foreign VC. This could induce an omitted-variable bias in the main regressions, and potentially raise issues about systematic differences between foreignbacked and non-foreign-backed companies. We address this concern by examining the portfolio company's EBIT/Assets at the time of listing. We collect data on the firm's EBIT/Assets at the time of the IPO from Compustat (for US listings), CSMAR (for Mainland China listings), and Factset (for listings elsewhere). We first address the issue of whether “firm quality" is an omitted variable by controlling for the firm's EBIT/Assets. Next, we construct a distribution of EBIT/Assets values for all foreign-backed (or foreign/JV-backed) companies. We then exclude from the sample any non-foreignbacked (or non-foreign/JV-backed) companies whose EBIT/Assets are in the upper/lower $5\%$ tails (for the $90\%$ interval sample) or the upper/lower $10\%$ tails (for the $80\%$ interval). We also estimate a two-stage model, where in the first stage we use the portfolio company's EBIT/Assets as an instrument to predict whether there is foreign backing or foreign/JV backing. For brevity, the results are not reported, but the main finding is that foreign backing is still significantly negatively associated with company listing on a mainland market. ## Discussion and Limitations Our results are consistent with our core hypotheses. The results suggest that foreign-backed companies are more likely than domestic-backed companies to list overseas, consistent with Hypothesis 1. This supports the idea that foreign VCs can help to achieve internationalization, arguably by utilizing their connections, financial resources, and institutional knowledge. The results also suggest that the tendency to IPO a company overseas depends upon governance quality in the domestic market (supporting Hypothesis 2). Syndication appears to be important in the internationalization of VC-backed companies. The presence of foreign VCs also increases the likelihood that a domestic-backed company will list abroad, or, conversely, decreases the likelihood that it will list domestically, supporting Hypothesis 3. Furthermore, consistent with Hypothesis 4, the likelihood that a foreign-backed company will list abroad increases with the total number of VC backers. The results also indicate that one mechanism of internationalization could be the use of top-tier intermediaries (supporting Hypothesis 5), suggesting that foreign ${\mathrm{VC}}s^{\prime}$ connections are a key avenue through which they contribute to the likelihood of international listing. It is worth acknowledging some limitations of this study. We have sought to address econometric concerns through the previously mentioned robustness tests. There are some alternative explanations that we cannot completely eliminate: we cannot eliminate the possibility that results reflect China's listing rules, or the difficulties that foreign VCs would have repatriating profits into their home currency (cf. China's governance). Future literature could look at the impact of recent reforms to foreign exchange controls on VC investment in China. Additionally, this paper focuses on international IPOs rather than international takeovers. Investigating the role of VC and PE funds in facilitating international takeovers is an avenue for future research. ## CONCLUSION This paper analyzes the role of foreign VCs in encouraging the internationalization of their portfolio companies. In this paper, we focus on investments in companies based in China. The focus on China enables us to specifically examine portfolio companies that might benefit from internationalization because it significantly improves their access to capital. We show that foreign-backed portfolio companies are significantly more likely than domestic companies to IPO overseas. The propensity of foreign backers to pursue an international listing varies with the quality of sovereign governance. The presence of foreign backers also increases the likelihood that a domestic-backed company will IPO overseas, suggesting that some types of syndicate diversity can be beneficial. Further, foreign VCs are more likely to use top-tier bankers, lawyers, and accountants when undertaking an IPO, suggesting that their connections with intermediaries are a key value driver of investments by foreign VCs. We take steps to mitigate concerns about endogeneity and sample selection. These results contribute to the literature on international business. Prior literature has examined the role of sovereign governance on VC and PE investment strategies. Additionally, some of the literature has examined the investment strategies of foreign VCs. We extend this analysis by examining the role of foreign VCs in encouraging internationalization through international IPOs. These results contribute to the literature on entrepreneurship, venture capital, and international business. Prior literature has attempted to identify the value drivers in VC/PE investment. We highlight that one such value driver can be internationalization. Conversely, prior literature indicates that geographic distance can be a disadvantage in VC/PE investment.We showthat even if foreign VCs might not always achieve a successful exit, they can create value by exposing portfolio companies to international markets. We contribute to the syndication literature by showing that foreign VCs increase the likelihood that a domestic-backed company will list abroad. We also highlight the importance of sovereign governance to the decision to list an entrepreneurial company abroad. Overall, these results demonstrate the importance of foreign VCs to entrepreneurial internationalization. ## ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS This paper benefited from comments received at the workshop on Venture Capital and Private Equity in the Asia Pacific Region (2011) and the AVCAL Research Roundtable (2011), and from presentations at the University of New South Wales and University of Technology, Sydney. The paper also significantly benefited from the comments of two anonymous reviewers, and from David Reeb (the editor). His research interests are in corporate finance, law and economics, and venture capital/private equity. He has published in influential finance and management journals. His PhDs are from the University of New South Wales, Tilburg University, and Leiden University. Jo-Ann Suchard is an Associate Professor in Banking and Finance at the University of New South Wales. Her research interests include venture capital and private equity, capital raising in debt and equity markets, and corporate governance. She is a Director of the Asian Finance Association, and organizes and hosts an annual online workshop on venture capital and private equity in Asia.

md_jainPredictorsPerformanceVenture2001.reference_markdown:
# Predictors of performance of venture capitalist-backed organizations  

Bharat A. Jain\*  

Department of Finance, Towson University, Towson, MD 21252,USA  

Accepted 17 August 1999  

## Abstract  

Venture capitalists seek investment opportunities in young, privately-held companies with promising growth prospects. In addition to supplying capital, venture capitalists are decision-making agents who participate in the governance of their ventures and attempt to influence objectives, strategy, structure, and control processes. This study develops and evaluates models examining the impact and relative importance of venture-capitalist factors, managerial strategy, industry structure variables, and their interactions on performance of venture capital-backed organizations. The models are evaluated based on their ability to predict whether the VC-backed venture will provide superior long-term performance. $\copyright$ 2001 Elsevier Science Inc. All rights reserved.  

Keywords: Venture capitalists; Strategic decision-making; Logit models; Initial public offerings  

### 1. Introduction  

Venture capital (VC) is defined as a professionally managed pool of risk capital invested in private companies atvariousstagesof theirdevelopmentandwherethe providers of capital actively participate in the decisionmaking process of their portfolio companies (Sahlman, 1990; Barry, 1994). Venture capitalists (henceforth VCs), typically seek investment opportunities in promising young entrepreneurial ventures about which there is little or no publicly available information. These ventures are usually far from a public offering and often have no revenues or marketable products when VCs become interested in them. The “good" VCs have the ability to address the “sorting problem" (Sahlman, 1990), i.e., separating the best entrepreneurial firms from marginal ones. In addition to providing capital, VCs use their industry specific knowledge, expertise, and contacts to assist entrepreneurs in strategic and operational planning, personnel and supplier selection, marketing, financing, monitoring, and even assuming managerial roles where necessary (Gormon and Sahlman, 1989; Macmillian et al., 1989; Barry et al., 1990). VCs often claim that the advising services they provide and the information they generate for their client companies are as important as the capital infused (Gompers, 1995).  

The functions performed by VCs have been widely recognized as key factors in promoting innovation and economic development (Bygrave and Timmons, 1992). VCs have been credited with creating entirely new industries and generating a more-than-proportionate share of growth in jobs and wealth. Their involvement has the potential to provide value to both investors as well as entrepreneurs. By virtue of their access to entrepreneurs and their business plans, VCs have the ability to assist investors by generating and acting on information to make decisions that reduce the risk of an investment. Similarly, entrepreneurs who are sometimes narrow technical specialists with limited managerial and business skills can benefit from the strategic guidance and inputs provided by VCs, who are often specialists in a particular industry, technology, or stage of development (Rock, 1987). Thus, VCs have the ability to select promising ventures and then through their active involvement, generate high risk-adjusted returns for investors. As a result, it is logical to expect strong long-run performance from VC-backed firms. Since VCs have been associated both with spectacular successes as well as numerous failures, it is clear that there are substantial differences in performance among them. Identifying factors that influence the performance of VC-backed organizations is likely to be an important step in understanding the functioning of the venture capital industry.  

The evidence on predictors of future performance of VCbacked organizations is however, scant. Researchers have focused either on measuring returns to VC firms or comparing the performance of VC-backed versus non-VC-backed ventures (Barry, 1994; Brav and Gompers, 1998). Recently, researchers have recognized the need to study the determinants of performance of VC-backed ventures. For example, Sapienza and Gupta (1994) suggest that it is important to study the nature of VC-entrepreneur interaction and its impact on future venture performance.  

This study attempts to address some of these issues by developing and testing a model that examines the significance and relative importance of VC factors, managerial strategy, industry structure attributes and their interactions as predictors of future performance of VC-backed organizations. The VC factors attempt to capture the impact of VC involvement in the venture firm. Managerial strategy variables capture the quality of strategic decisions implemented by entrepreneurs at various stages of development. Industry structure variables are included to capture the competitive environment. In addition, the model includes an indirect effect of VC factors on performance through managerial strategy. The indirect effect is included to measure the economic impact of the joint decision-making environment, which is a unique characteristic of VC involvement. Prior to VC involvement, entrepreneurs are solely responsible for setting, monitoring, and adjusting strategic direction and standard operating procedures. VC involvement produces new competencies, resources, and perspectives that can lead to a fundamental shift in organizational goals. Although entrepreneurs are still primarily responsible for strategic direction and managing the day-to-day operations, they are now required to consult and share decision-making authority with VCs. The joint decision-making environment provides VCs with an opportunity to influence goals, priorities, actions, and strategic attributes, and also bring much-needed discipline to the organization with the introduction of formal control processes. On the other hand, the downside to sharing decision-making authority includes increased agency problems, slower decision-making, loss of focus, and increased potential for conflict, all of which can adversely affect venture performance (Sapienza and Korsgaard, 1996). The net impact of joint decision-making on performance depends on the strategic fit between VCs and entrepreneurs and the extent to which they achieve effective coordination and integration of their objectives and actions.  

The research model is tested on a sample of VC-backed organizations that subsequently issued initial public offerings (IPOs). VC factors, managerial strategy, and industry structure variables are measured at or prior to the IPO. A VC-backed venture is classified as a performer if it demonstrates an increase in operating performance in the post-IPO years compared to its pre-IPO level. The predictive ability of the various models are evaluated on their sorting efficiency, i.e., ability to differentiate between performing and non-performing VC-backed organizations. Managerial implications are also discussed.  

### 2. Research model  

Fig. 1 provides an overview of the research model. The bold arrows represent the direct effects of VC factors, managerial strategy, and industry structure variables on performance. The variables within the VC factors group measure the effectiveness of VCs in conducting activities such as deal origination, screening, evaluation, contract structuring, and post-investment monitoring (Tyebjee and Bruno, 1984). Managerial strategy variables represent strategic decisions evaluated and implemented by entrepreneurs (henceforth, managers) in their pursuit of competitive advantage. Finally, industry structure variables capture the competitive environment and are included as control variables.  

In order to capture the joint decision-making environment, the model includes an indirect effect of VC factors on performance represented by a path through managerial strategy. Although the primary responsibility to set strategy, make ongoing strategic adjustments, and carry out day-today operations rests with managers, VCs have the opportunity to participate in the decision-making process and exert their influence. Depending on factors such as stage of development, extent of innovation being pursued, and managerial expertise, some VCs may choose to take a hands-off approach while others may actively participate in the decision-making process (Sapienza and Gupta, 1994). When the VC-entrepreneur interaction is low, the direct effects capture the impact of VC factors on performance. On the other hand, where VC-manager interaction is high, the indirect effects are likely to be strong. A description of the VC factors, strategy and industry structure variables, and their hypothesized effect on venture performance are described below.  

#### 2.1. VC factors  

Three sets of VC related variables are explored within this category: (1) quality of due diligence, (2) participation in the corporate governance, and (3) experience.  

The major source of value added and the fundamental reason for the existence of VCs is their ability to originate, screen, and evaluate promising entrepreneurial firms. The process of VC involvement usually starts with the originating VC becoming aware of high growth, promising, capitalstarved, young companies that are not yet visible to the public. During the screening process, the originating VCs review and evaluate the business plan, management commitment/skills, product uniqueness, intensity of competition, and quality and competence of ventures’ managerial teams and the CEO (Sapienza and Gupta, 1994). After discovering a promising prospect, VCs do not make a binding commitment to provide financing but instead send the proposal to other VCs for their review (Lerner, 1994a,b,c). Organizations in which investments are made only if several independent and knowledgeable observers agree, may be superior to ones where projects are funded after a single affirmative decision (Perez, 1986; Sah and Stiglitz, 1986).  

![](images/eff4919bc8dab02ab7caecbab27ba7640ddf7e1d6bc41c470048a5776fbe36f0.jpg)  
Fig. 1. Research model.  

Another major reason for VCs to circulate details of their prospective deals is to try and convince other VCs to commit to providing capital. VCs tend to syndicate their investments, i.e., join together by pooling capital, knowledge, expertise, and other resources when investing in promising prospects (Bygrave and Timmons, 1992). A measure of the quality of the originating VC's due diligence is the ability to attract a large number of other VCs to join the syndicate. A strong investing syndicate has the potential to positively influence venture performance in several ways. Larger-sized syndicates are more capable of raising substantial capital for the venture at favorable terms for current and future needs, achieve efficient risk diversification, and entice institutional investors, top-tier investment bankers, and high-quality analysts. Further, larger syndicates provide incentives to the originating VC to closely monitor venture performance. Failure results in loss of reputation capital and diminished ability to put together future deals. Thus, highquality due diligence by the originating VC results in largersized syndicates, which in turn leads to superior financing, more effective monitoring, and stronger institutional support. Therefore, a positive relation between quality of due diligence and venture performance is expected.  

Participation in the corporate governance allows VCs to exert influence and ensure that managers pursue a valuemaximizing agenda. The timing and extent of VC involvement in the corporate governance depends on the amount of capital and resources being provided. VCs that are willing to commit substantial resources are naturally in a better position to negotiate stronger participation in the corporate governance. The extent of VC participation in the corporate governance is explored through strength of board representation and duration of service on the board. VCs are almost always represented on the board and, typically, occupy two seats or about one third of the director positions (Barry et al., 1990). A stronger proportional VC representation on the board increases manager's receptivity to advice and therefore, enhances VCs ability to initiate change and reshape decision-making processes. Therefore, a positive relationship between VC board representation with venture performance is expected.  

VCs usually take long-term board positions in ventures and typically assist them for about half their corporate lives prior to the IPO. Their involvement on the board usually continues well after the company has gone public and they continue to provide access to capital and other resources (Barry et al., 1990). However, the main impact of VCs on the board is likely to be prior to the IPO when major financial, operational, and strategic decisions need to be made in preparation for the public offering. The longer the length of service by VCs on the board of directors, the greater is the ability to monitor, observe, oversee, and exercise beneficial influence (Barry et al., 1990). On the other hand, extended presence on the board can also indicate that the venture is marginal and reflective of the difficulty the VC is experiencing in bringing the company to the market. Thus, the direction of relationship between duration of VC service on the board and venture performance is ambiguous.  

Experience is another element of VC effectiveness. Experienced VCs should be in a stronger position to conduct rigorous due diligence, put together powerful syndicates, and exert influence on the board. In the post-investment stage, experienced VCs should have a relative advantage in assessing market trends, identifying positioning opportunities, providing supplier and customer management support, selecting timing of the IPO and future financing, and thereby, add value to the strategic and operational planning process (Barry, 1994; Lerner, 1994a,b,c; Gompers, 1995). Therefore, a positive relationship between VC experience and venture performance is expected.  

#### 2.2. Managerial strategy variables  

The six managerial strategy variables explored in the research model are: (1) extent of innovation being pursued, (2) selection of investment banker, (3) stage of development at time of IPO, (4) managerial ownership retention, (5) product scope, and (6) asset mix and utilization.  

Managers must determine what innovations to pursue, how to pursue them, whether pursuit of innovation is likely to be profitable, and whether innovation will provide a sustainable competitive advantage in the face of strong imitation efforts by rivals (Rumelt, 1987). Although highly innovative firms are riskier, they have the potential to provide spectacular results if their growth and innovation are successfully managed. Ventures pursuing innovative strategies also benefit from the experience, perspectives, market contacts, and resources provided by VCs. Therefore, a positive relation between level of innovation being pursued and performance is expected.  

A crucial strategic decision facing venture managers contemplating an IPO is the selection of the investment banker charged with the responsibility to market, distribute, and underwrite the securities. Often, the entire success or failure of the going public process depends on this decision. The selection of an investment banker is a two-way matching problem since both parties incur considerable risk and resource outlays, and therefore, the decision to come together needstobe carefully evaluated.Investmentbankersevaluate management capabilities, product uniqueness, growth potential, vision, business strategy, and a host of other factors before agreeing to market the firm. Similarly, managers use several criteria in deciding which investment banker is best suited to take the firm public. A measure of successful strategic posturing by venture managers is the ability to attract prestigious investment bankers to take the firm public. Prestigious investment bankers have the ability to add value as a result of their superior due diligence skills, marketing efforts, and certification and monitoring functions (Carter et al., 1998). Therefore, a positive relation between investment bank prestige and venture performance is expected.  

New entrepreneurial firms go through several stages of growth patterns such as conception, development, first production, commercialization, growth, etc. Managers need to decide when and at what stage of venture development should they issue an IPO. The most appropriate course of action is, however, far from clear. Firms that go public prematurely risk rejection from the capital markets due to an insufficient track record of sales and profitability and uncertainties associated with unresolved demand, product and process design, availability of skilled employees, raw materials, and channels of distribution (Sapienza and Gupta, 1994). Further premature offerings prevent managers from ensuring that fully developed marketable products, appropriate management teams, and standard operating procedures are in place prior to going public. All these factors are likely to be important prerequisites to future venture performance. On the other hand, ventures that go public at a later stage in their development may experience a decline in their post-issue performance as a result of a growth slowdown. Therefore, a relationship between stage of development at the time of IPO and post-issue performance is expected.  

Deciding on the extent of managerial ownership retention in the post-IPO firm is an important strategic consideration.  

The process of going public leads to dilution of ownership of the original entrepreneurs. Jensen (1986) suggests that a dilution of ownership of insiders is likely to weaken the alignment of their incentives with that of other shareholders, leading to the classic agency problem. In the absence of any mechanism to overcome the agency problem, the performance of the firm is likely to decline. Retaining substantial managerial ownership in the post-IPO firm is one credible method of overcoming this type of an incentive problem as it provides incentives to insiders to continue to stay involved in the firm and provide positive guidance. A positive relationship between managerial ownership retention and venture performance is expected.  

Venture managers need to decide whether to compete on a broad front or follow a niche strategy. The extensive debate in the literature over whether new ventures should pursue niche strategies or compete on a broad front suggests that this is a complex issue with no straightforward prescriptions (Carter et al., 1994). Conventional wisdom suggests that smaller, newer firms should avoid direct competition with larger players and pursue profitable niche strategies. On the other hand, competing in several segments provides the potential to exploit economies of scale and scope. The direction of relationship between product scope and performance is, therefore, ambiguous.  

Finally, asset mix and utilization is an important strategic attribute that bears directly on operational efficiency and therefore, impacts performance (Hambrick and Lei, 1985). Managers need to set up efficient control processes so as to optimize the utilization of their asset mix.A positive relation between asset mix and utilization and venture performance is expected.  

#### 2.3. Industry structure variables  

Several studies have suggested that industry structure variables such as concentration, barriers to entry, elasticity of demand, etc., have a significant impact on performance (Schmalensee, 1981; Rumelt, 1987). Since VCs tend to focus on a narrow set of industries, it is unlikely that industry  structure  variables can  explain differences  in performance among VC-backed ventures. However, industry attributes are included in the model as control variables. The industry structure variables selected are drawn from the literature and include industry concentration, industry growth, industry advertising intensity, and industry R&D intensity (Montgomery, 1985; Sharma and Kesner, 1996).  

### 3. Sample description and research methodology  

#### 3.1.Sample selection and data description  

A sample of 104 VC-backed ventures that subsequently issued IPOs are collected for the period 1982-1990 from  

Going Public: The IPO Reporter and the Venture Capital Journal. The sample is further segmented into performing and non-performing ventures. Performing ventures are defined as firms that demonstrate an increase in their post-IPO operating return on assets compared to their pre-IPO levels. Thus, a venture is categorized as a performer if OPRA (post)-OPRA (pre) $\geq0$ ,where OPRA(pre) is the operating return on assets of the venture in the fiscal year prior to the IPO and OPRA(post) is the average operating return on assets of the venture in the first, second, and third year after the IPO. Firms that demonstrate a decline in operating return on assets compared to their pre-IPO levels are categorized as non-performing. This definition results in a sample of 26 performing and 78 non-performing ventures.  

Table 1 provides a description of the independent variables, their measures, and the expected sign of the relationship with venture performance. The quality of VC due diligence is measured by the size of the investing syndicate, i.e., number of VCs that take an equity position in the IPO of the venture (NUMVC). The variable PROPVC measures proportion of VCs on the board while BD represents the time between the VC joining the board of the venture and the IPO. As suggested in the literature, the age of the originating VC is used as a proxy for experience (Barry et al., 1990). The stage of venture development at the IPO is measured by the logarithm of the gross proceeds raised at the IPO (LSIZE). The extent of technical innovation being pursued (INNOV) reflected by the risk of the venture (Sapienza and Gupta, 1994) is measured by the standard deviation of market returns. The post-IPO managerial ownership retention including VC stake is represented by the variable ALPHA (Jain and Kini, 1994). The investment bank prestige (PRESTIGE) is measured using the nine point Carter and Manaster prestige scale (see Carter and Manaster, 1990 for details). The breadth of product line (SCOPE) is measured by the number of four-digit SIC codes assigned to the firm's product line. Asset mix and utilization is measured by asset turnover (AMU) (Grover, 1993). Industry concentration (CONC) is assessed by the Herfindel four firm index. Industry growth (GR) is computed by measuring the 3- year industry sales growth in the years prior to the public offering. Industry advertising intensity (ADV) and R&D intensity (R&D) are measured by taking the average of advertising expenses and R&D expenses as a percentage of sales for all firms in the same industry as the VCbacked venture.  

A correlation matrix is examined to assess the potential for multicollinearity problems. There is some evidence to indicate significant correlation among some within group as well as between groups of variables. The issue of correlated variables is addressed by carefully constructing models to avoid multicollinearity problems and with a factor analytical model described later in Section 4.

#### 3.2. Methodology  

Initially, univariate logit models are estimated to identify significant predictors of performance. The dependent variable is the probability that the venture is a performer. The independent variables are drawn from the VC factors, managerial strategy, and industry structure groups. The predictive ability of variables capturing the interaction between VC factors and managerial strategy are also examined.  

Next, several multivariate logit models are evaluated to compare the predictive ability of each of the three groups of variables and their combinations. The predictive ability of the logit models are evaluated based on three measures: (1) percentage of performing ventures correctly classified, (2) overall classification accuracy, and (3) weighted efficiency. The weighted efficiency measure is included to overcome some of the problems with the overall classification rate, which can be misleading when the two groups to be classified are present in significantly different proportions in the population (Korobow and Stuhr, 1985; Wertheim and Lynn, 1993). The weighted efficiency measure proposed by Korobow and Stuhr (1986) is defined in this study as the product of the overall percentage correctly classified, the percentage of performers correctly classified, and the ratio of the number of performers correctly identified to the total number of firms identified as performers. In a perfect model, the product of the three components will equal 100 percent. In a less-than-perfect model, this measure will be sensitive to both the number of performers correctly identified and the percentage of firms identified as performers.  

The overall correct classification rate is also compared with a benchmark obtained using the Morrison's proportional chance criteria (Morrison, 1969). In a sample with 26 performers and 78 non-performers, the overall correct classification rate based on the chance criterion is 62.5 percent. In order to establish generalizability of the results, the classification accuracy of all models are based on the Lachenbruch procedure (Lachenbruch, 1975; Wertheim and Lynn, 1993). The cut-off probability for all models is 0.50.  

### 4. Empirical results  

#### 4.1. Summary statistics  

Table 2 provides a comparison of performing and nonperforming ventures. The mean values for the two groups as well as the $t\cdot$ -statistics and the non-parametric Wilcoxon sign statistic are reported. The results suggest significant differences between the two groups on several dimensions. For instance, there is a significant difference between performers and non-performers on the quality of VC due diligence. The mean syndicate size is 8.26 for performers versus 4.28 for non-performers (the difference is statistically significant at the 0.01 level). VCs are also more involved in the corporate governance of performing ventures compared to non-performing ventures. The proportion of VCs on the board is

35.30 percent for performers versus 24.20 percent for nonperformers (statistically significant at the 0.01 level). While performing firms are characterized by longer VC service on the board (36.01 vs. 31.35) months and associated with more experienced VCs (14.58 vs. 12.33) years compared to their non-performing counterparts, the differences are not statistically significant.  

The results in Table 2 also suggest significant differences between performers and non-performers on several managerial strategy variables. The mean IPO issue size is 32.58 million for performers versus 18.31 million for nonperformers and the difference is statistically significant. This supports the conjecture that performing ventures go through several rounds of private financing until they achieve efficient scale before going public. Managers of performing ventures retain significantly higher post-IPO ownership, pursue higher levels of innovation, and demonstrate higher asset utilization compared to their non-performing counterparts. While the mean value of investment banker prestige is significantly higher for performers, the median is not significantly different. There is no significant difference in the breadth of the product line between the two groups. Finally, the results show that there are no significant differences between the two groups on industry structure variables.  

#### 4.2. Univariate logit models  

Table 3 provides the results of estimating univariate logit models. The results are consistent with the comparisons in Table 2. While all VC factor variables are positively related to venture performance, only the size of the syndicate and proportion of board seats occupied are significant. Four of the six managerial strategy variables (LSIZE, INNOV, ALPHA, and AMU) are significant and positively related to venture performance while industry structure variables are all insignificant.

The results of univariate logit models that include interactions between VC factors and managerial strategy indicate several significant variables. For instance, interactions between strength of VC syndicate and managerial strategy variables such as stage of venture development at IPO, extent of innovation, and ownership retention are significant predictors of venture performance. Further, interactions between the above three managerial strategy variables and VC involvement in corporate governance are also significant predictors of performance.  

#### 4.3. Multivariate logit models  

The estimation results and the predictive performance of the various multivariate logit models are reported in Table 4. The first model (INDUSTRY) includes all four industry structure variables. The $\mathrm{X}^{2}$ value indicates that the overall model is not significant and none of the four industry structure variables are significantly related to performance. The overall correct percentage is 59.60 percent, which is below the 62.5 percent obtained by the Morrison's chance criteria (Morrison, 1969). The percentage of performers correctly identified is 34 percent and the weighted efficiency of the model is only 5.40 percent. Thus, industry structure variables are poor predictors of VC-backed venture performance.  

The second model (FIRM), includes the four significant managerial strategy variables identified from the univariate analysis. The $\mathrm{X}^{2}$ value is significant at the 0.01 level and three of the four variables are significantly related to the probability of venture performing. The predictive ability of the FIRM model exceeds the rate predicted by the chance criteria and shows a substantial improvement over the INDUSTRY model. The weighted efficiency is 17.30 percent while the overall classification rate and percentage of performers correctly identified are 75 percent and 46.15 percent, respectively.  

The third model (VC) includes all four VC factor variables and is significant at the 0.01 level. The model provides a substantial improvement in predictive performance compared to either the INDUSTRY or FIRM models. The VC model has an overall correct classification rate of 76.90 percent and correctly classifies 53.84 percent of the performers. The VC model also has a higher weighted efficiency of 23.32 percent.  

The next step is to investigate whether VC factors and strategy variables as separate predictors in the same model outperform models that include either VC factors alone or strategy variables alone. To test this proposition, a fourth model (COMBINE) including significant variables (identified from univariate analysis) from the VC factors and strategy group is estimated. The COMBINE model provides a substantial improvement in predictive accuracy over both the VC and FIRM models. The weighted efficiency is 38.90 percent while the overall correct rate and percentage of performers correctly classified are 77.00 percent and 65.38 percent, respectively.

#### 4.4. Factor analytic logit model  

The multivariate analyses, thus far, have focused on examining the direct effects of VC factors, managerial strategy, and industry structure variables on performance. The research model also predicts the indirect effect of VC factors (path through managerial strategy) on venture performance. The impact of this indirect path depends on the extent of strategic fit between VCs and managers. One method to include strategic fit in the model building exercise is to add interaction terms (Schoonhoven, 1981). Researchers, however, point to several problems with this approach such as difficulty in interpreting results and multicollinearity problems as a result of the interaction terms being highly correlated with the terms that compose them (Dewar and Werbel, 1979). Further, researchers have to specify the functional form of the relationship, which can be difficult, especially when dealing with a large number of potential interactions, as is the case with this study (Alexander and Randolph, 1985). To overcome these problems, a factor analytic approach similar to that of West (1985) is adopted. The basic assumption is that each variable can be expressed as a linear combination of hidden factors that affect the variable and possibly other variables. A study of the factors can also provide insight into the critical success factors affecting performance of VC-backed ventures.  

The 14 variables from the VC factors, strategy, and industry structure groups are subjected to a principal component analysis with varimax rotation. Based on eigenvalues greater than 1 criteria, a four-factor solution is selected, which accounts for 64 percent of the variance. Factor 1 accounts for 26.97 percent while the remaining three factors account for 17.72 percent, 9.44 percent, and 8.65 percent of the variance, respectively. The results are reported in Table 5. Only loadings greater than 0.50 are used to interpret the factors.  

The first factor can be named VC-manager strategic fit. Variables that load on this factor include strength of VC syndicate, VC representation on the board, stage of venture development at IPO, investment banker prestige, and asset mix and utilization. This factor captures the fit between VC strengths-expertise and managerial strategy variables. Factor 2 can be named long-term commitment of VC-managers. Variables that load on this factor include duration of VC service on the board and managerial ownership retention in the post-IPO firm. The third factor is harder to interpret and can be named VC selection criteria. Variables that load on this factor include product breadth (negative loading), extent of innovation being pursued, and VC experience. Ventures with narrow focus and pursuing high levels of innovation are well positioned to benefit from VC experience. The fourth factor can be named industry barriers to entry. Since this factor has a single loading (industry R&D intensity), it needs to be interpreted with caution.  

To measure the effectiveness of these four factors as predictors of venture performance, a factor analytic logit model is estimated using the procedure adopted by West (1985). The factor scores are used as variables in estimating a maximum likelihood logit model with venture performance (performing vs. non-performing) as the dependent variable. The results are reported in Table 6. The VCmanager strategic fit and long-term commitment are significantly positively related while the VC selection criteria is significantly negatively related to venture performance. The industry barriers to entry factor is not significantly related to venture performance. The predictive accuracy of the factor analytic model is substantially higher than the multivariate logit models reported in Table 4. The weighted efficiency is 44.54 percent while the overall correct classification rate and percentage of performers correctly classified are 84.60 percent and 80.76 percent, respectively. Therefore, inclusion of the indirect effect of VC factors on performance significantly enhances the predictive ability of the model.
