# Mixed Ownership and Firm Performance: Evidence from the Chinese Venture Capital Industry  

Mixed Ownership and Firm Performance: Evidence from the Chinese Venture Capital Industry   
Bin Kei and Lanfang Wang2   
August 12, 2020   
We wish to thank two anonymous reviewers, Jing Liu, Zengquan Li, Jue Wang, and workshop participants at the CKGSB, Beijing Technology and Business University, and Shanghai University of Finance and Economics research retreat for helpful comments. We gratefully acknowledge financial support from the National Natural Science Foundation of China Funds (No. 71672106).   
1 Department of Accounting, Business School, National University of Singapc., Mochtar Riady Building, BIZ 1, # 07-53, 15 Kent Ridge Drive, Singapore 119245.Tel: $+65$ 6601 3 133. Fax: $+65$ 6773 6493. Email: bizk @ nus.edu.sg.   
2 SHU-UTS SILC Business School, Shanghai University, 20 Cher gzht ng Road, Shanghai, China. Tel: +862165908983. Fax: +862165106924. Email: lanft ng、2.g @ mail.shu.edu.cn.  

# Abstr ic'  

We examine the impact of mixed own rs ip en the performance of venture capital (VC) firms in China. We use successful/uns. cessful exits from VC-financed entrepreneurial companies and number of patent zpplicatisns by VC-financed companies as proxies for VC firms’ performance. Consistent w;\*h existing research on the inferior performance of SOEs relative to non-SOEs, we fira chat on average government-controlled VC firms (GVCs) underperform domes'ic pivate investors-controlled VC firms (PVCs). More importantly, we find that in'ro'ucing minority private investors (i.e., mixed ownership) helps improve the perform anc $\mathbf{\hat{\Pi}}$ of GVCs. However, we find no evidence that introducing minority government investo 3 (i.e., mixed ownership) helps improve the performance of PVCs. Our results prr vi'e ielevant information to the ongoing debate on the role of the government invest srs ans. private investors in developing the VC industry in emerging markets.  

Key words: venture capital; mixed ownership; performance; innovation; patents  

JEL c0des: G24, G38, 031  

Data Availability: Data used in this study are publicly available from the sources identified in the paper.  

## 1. Introduction  

Prior research shows that state owned enterprises (SOEs) are generally not as efficient as non-SOEs in resource allocation and firm performance (e.g., Boardman and Vining 1989; Ehrlich et al. 1994; Liu and Siu 2012). While privatization is believed to be the most effective approach to solving the inefficiency of SOEs (Shleifer 1998), many countries still maintain a significant list of SOEs in the name of national interests (OECD 2006; Kowalski et al. 2013). As an alternative approach, nu.ed ownership, where a business enterprise is jointly owned by both state capita! auu private capital, has often been suggested as a possible solution to the inefficit.rcy of SOEs (Garvin and Bosso 2008; OECD 2012; Yang 2017). While mixed owners'ip is popular around the world, the merits of such an organizational form are stil. 'iot.y debated around the world (Wang et al. 2017; Hodge and Greve 2016).  

The objective of this study is $\cdot\circ$ provide a direct assessment of the performance of mixed ownership in the Chin<re oe nture capital (VC) industry. Though started only around 1998, China's VC industry has since experienced explosive growth. More importantly, the past derat'? nas also observed the establishment of China's own nascent domestic VC indust, most notably, the creation of hundreds of VC firms partially or wholly funded by various government linked entities. Many of the government-linked Chinese VC firms are in the form of mixed ownership.  

While theoretical justifications could be made for the government's intervention in the development of the VC industry and entrepreneurship (Hall 2002; Amit et al. 1998; Lerner 2010), it is still hotly debated whether and to what extent the government should be involved in the VC industry development (Lerner 2008, 2010). Much less is known on the performance of VC's mixed ownership in financing entrepreneurial companies, which are believed to be critical to a nation’s innovation and economic growth (Schumpeter 1934; Lerner 2010).  

We divide all domestic Chinese VC firms into two types, GVCs, defined as VC firms that receive the majority of their funding from either government agencies or statecontrolled enterprises (SOEs) or both, and PVCs, defined as vC firms that receive the majority of their funding from domestic private inve-tonc. GVCs  and  PVCs  are equivalent to SOEs and non-SOEs, respectively, in ti e traditional SOE literature. We further divide GVCs into two types, GVC1, defin. i as GVCs that receive all their funding from government agencies or SOE c' bth, and GVC2, defined as GVCs that receive some minority funding from pri ate investors. We also divide PVCs into two types, PVC1, defined as PVCs that ,\*ceive all their funding from private investors, and PVC2, defined as PVCs that r\~ei ·e some minority funding from government agencies and/or SOEs. GVC2 and $\partial\mathbf{\Omega}^{\setminus}\mathbf{V}\mathbf{C}^{\prime}{}_{\angle}$ are mixed ownership firms because they are jointly owned by the governmen\* (including SOEs) and private investors. We also refer to GVC1, GVC2, and ?VC2 as government-linked VC firms because they all receive at least some funding from government-linked entities.  

Before we assess the performance of mixed ownership (i.e., GVC2 and PVC2), we first examine the performance of GVCs (i.e., GVC1+GVC2) versus PVCs (i.e., PVC1 $^+$ PVC2) because prior research tends to focus on the performance of GVCs and PVCs as a whole. Following prior research, we measure a VC firm's performance using two performance evaluation metrics: successful exit from a VC-financed entrepreneurial company and the number of patent applications filed by a VC-financed entrepreneurial company during the first two years since a VC firm's first round investment. We assume that all VCs care about these two performance indicators.? Following prior research (e.g., Nahata et al. 2014), we focus on the lead VC firm because it plays a dominant role in mentoring and monitoring the entrepreneurial company.  

Ex ante the relative performance of GVCs versus PVCs :s difficult to predict due to conflicting institutional forces. Conventional econom:\~ ..sdom, referred to as the incentive hypothesis (Shleifer 1998; Lerner 2010), wot'd predict GVCs to underperform PVCs due to the well-known agency problems asso. ated with government ownership. For example, GVCs could pursue political age.?da' , which in turn could negatively affect GVCs’ managerial incentives. In a& itin, GVCs may find it difficult to use highpowered incentive compensation con\*racts due to rigid government regulations (Chen et al. 2013). Therefore, managers ^f (V Cs may not have the same incentives as managers of PVCs to acquire private  forination in the selection of entrepreneurial companies for investment or closely monitr their funded companies.  

On the other i. \*nd, GVCs may have a competitive advantage relative to PVCs due to their inherent government connections, referred to as the political connection hypothesis. China is a representative emerging market economy, where many important aspects of Chinese firms’ operations are significantly influenced by various government agencies, including input and output factor markets, taxes, bank and public equity financing, etc. Prior research shows that driven by various political and economic incentives such as political tournament and social stability (Li and Zhou 2005; Lin et al. 2004), local Chinese government officials have a strong incentive to provide a variety of preferential treatments to the Chinese SOEs under their jurisdictions, including information sharing, tax concessions and easy access to bank and public equity financing (Aharony et al. 2000; Brandt and Li 2003; Cull anr X. 2003). Because GVCs' performance depends on the success of their funde.' entrepreneurial companies, we expect GVC-funded companies to directly or indirec.'< benefit from GVCs′ government connections, especially the entrepreneuria' mpanies that are located in the same province as the GVCs’ headquarte of course, PVCs could partially offset this competitive disadvantage by estabn.ching their own political connections, making the relative performance of GVCs v<rst  PVCs difficult to predict ex ante.  

Our sample contains \~ 65 / Chinese entrepreneurial companies funded by 417 lead domestic VC firms over th period 2000-2009. Consistent with the extant broad literature on SOEs vs. non-SCEs and prior Chinese VC literature (e.g., Zhang and Mayes 2018), we find that GVCs significantly underperform PVCs in terms of successful exit. In terms of the quantity of annual patent applications filed by VC-funded companies over the first two years since the lead VC firm's first round investment, GVCs also underperform PVCs. Overall, these results suggest that the incentive hypothesis dominates the political connection hypothesis in explaining the underperformance of GVCs versus PVCs.  

Next we examine whether mixed ownership can help improve the performance of GVCs by comparing the relative performance of GVC1 versus GVC2. Ex ante the answer is unclear because it is far from clear whether minority private investors have any significant influence in the operations of GVCs. With regard to successful exit, we find that both GVC1 and GVC2 underperform PVCs, but there is evidence that GVC2 significantly outperform GVC1. We find similar results for the quantity of annual patent applications but the results are not always significant. Overall, u \*se results suggest that if properly structured, introducing minority private investor ra. significantly improve the performance of GVCs. However, the performance oi GVC2 is still inferior to that of PVCs, suggesting that complete privatization may st'"i be the most effective remedy to GVCs' inefficiencies.  

Our final analysis examines vhr .her mixed ownership can help improve the performance of PVCs by comparing the relative performance of PVC1 versus PVC2. Again the answer is unclear ex ant 'because introducing minority government investors has both costs and benefits  s nored in the incentive hypothesis and political connection hypothesis. Empirically w · find little evidence of a significant performance difference between PVC1 and ?VC2. These results suggest no evidence of a positive net benefit resulting from adding government minority investors in PVCs.  

We recognize the endogeneity of different types of VC firms and VC-financed entrepreneurial companies. We attempt to address the endogeneity challenge in several ways and find similar inferences. Despite our efforts, we acknowledge that our results could still be caused by the endogeneity of the VC ownership types and therefore the reader should interpret our results with caution.  

We contribute to two distinctive streams of literatures. Our first contribution is to the emerging literature on government-sponsored VC firms. As noted in a review paper by Da Rin et al. (2013), governments around the world support VC firms in a variety of ways, such as giving tax credits, matching funds that augment private capital commitments, and direct government ownership of VC funds, but research on the role of government policies remains scarce. With regard to government ownership of VC firms, there is a small literature on the performance consequences of g vernment ownership of VC firms. Our study differs from this extant literature in s-a. important ways.  

First, we are the first study to compare the relative performance of mixed ownership VC firms (i.e., GVC2 and PVC2) versus o.'.er types of government-linked VC firms (i.e., GVC1 and PVC1) and find iver sting results new to the literature. Presumably due to data limitations, .or studies in the extant literature examine VC firms where the government is a min ?rity investor only, i.e., PVC2 (e.g., Wallsten 2000; Brander et al. 2010; Cumming ^nc iacIntosh 2004) or VC firms wholly owned by the government only, i.e., GVC: (e.g., Cumming et al. 2017). A notable exception is Brander et al. (2015) who examine th VC firms wholly owned by government entities (referred to as government-ow.rea VC firms or GOVCs) and privately owned VC firms in which there is a limited partner or other significant investor wholly owned by a government entity (referred to as government-supported VC firms or GSVCs). Brander et al.'s GOVCs are equivalent to our GVC1 while their GSVCs are similar to our PVC2. However, Brander et al. do not compare the performance of GVC1 versus PVC2. More importantly, they do not consider GVC2 and PVC1.  

Second, we are one of the first studies to examine the performance of government-sponsored VC firms in an emerging market. Most existing studies (e.g.. Cumming et al. 2017 and Brander et al. 2015) primarily focus on VC firms in developed countries. A priori it is unclear whether their findings are generalizable to VC firms in emerging markets where there is a lack of developed infrastructures and institutions necessary for efficient business operations (Khanna et al. 2010) and therefore the roles and performance of government-sponsored VC firms could t\~ significantly different. Zhang and Mayes (2018) also examine the performar c GVCs but they do not distinguish GVC1 versus GVC2.  

Third, because we focus on one single count. , we are able to invest significant effort to  develop  a  comprehensive  and ·ep esentative  sample  of  VC-financed entrepreneurial companies, thus red. cirg the concern of potential sample selection biases. This is a significant contribt cion because the two primary commercial VC data used by prior researchers, Thoic onOne (formerly known as VentureXpert) and VentureSource (formerly kn wn as VentureOne), are known for incomplete coverage and lack of details on the rovs"d VC-funded companies (Kaplan et al. 2002; Maats et al. 2011; Da Rin et al. $2\lambda^{1}3,$  

Our findings carry important implications for the ongoing debate in China and many other emerging markets on how to support entrepreneurship and the local VC industry. The superior performance of PVCs relative to GVCs suggests the importance of supporting the development of PVCs so that they can play a more significant role in developing a nation's local VC industry and entrepreneurship. More importantly, the better performance of GVC2 relative to GVC1 also suggests that even if a local government wishes to develop the sector of GVCs, it can do better in performance by adopting a mixed ownership structure. On the other hand, the similar performance results for PVC1 and PVC2 suggest no evidence that PVCs can improve performance by introducing government investor capital as minority investors.  

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 discusses data sources and sample selection. Section 3 introduces the regression models. Section 4 examines the performance differences of GVCs versus PVCs as a whole. Section 5 reports the regression results for P3s (i.e., GVC1 versus GVC2 and pvC1 versus PVC2). Section 6 discusses several robustness checks. Section 7 concludc.  

## 2. Data sources and sample selection  

### 2.1. Data sources  

The data on VC firms and t.ir funded companies used in this study come from CVSOURCE, a leading VC ?rd or:vate equity database with an exclusive focus on China. Because VC firms ai not required to publicly disclose their investment portfolio data, the quality of data c. VC-funded companies from existing commercial databases commonly used in ths extant academic research has always been a concern (Kaplan et al. 2002; Maats et al. 2011; Da Rin et al. 2013). Our research indicates that CVSOURCE's coverage of VC-funded companies is relatively complete. Specifically, we compare the quantity of VC investment between CVSOURCE and The Annual Report on China's VC Industry Development, an authoritative year book jointly published by China's National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC), the government regulator of Chinese VC/PE firms during our sample period, and China Venture Capital & Private Equity  

Association. According to an interim regulation on the Administration of VC Firms that took effect in early 2006, all VC firms operating in China have been required since 2006 to register with the relevant local government VC administration agency in order to be eligible for receiving various preferential government treatments such as tax concessions and government funding. According to a 2011 VC survey conducted by the NDRC in Beijing, Shanghai, Jiangsu, Zhejiang, and Guangdong, the regions with the most VC firms, only approximately $12.86\%$ of the surveyed VC firms un'n't plan to register with the government (The Annual Report on China's VC Industy  velopment 2012, p.235).4 According to The Annual Report on China's VC i. dustry Development for the the available years 2006-2012, the total number of VC investment deals over the period 2006-2012 is 9,596. The comparable figurr α <co ding to CVSOURCE is 10,128.6 This comparison suggests that CVSOURCI 's overage of VC-funded companies is relatively complete.  

We rely on the inforratit  provided by CVSOURCE and a comprehensive Chinese company registrati  database developed by China's State Administration for Industry  and  Commer (SAIC)  to define the  VC ownershiptypes (http://gsxt.saic.gov.c.r). We obtain Chinese companies’ patent data from China's State Intellectual Property Rights Office (SIPO) and patent citation data from the Google Patent Citations database (www.google.com/patent). We use both computer programs and manual labor to match the companies in CVSOURCE with the companies in SIPO by company name. The data used to define the other regression variables come from CVSOURCE and other public sources noted in the appendix of variable definitions.  

### 2.2. Sample selection  

Consistent with the VC literature, we define a VC firm as a fund management entity that manages one or more VC funds. If a VC fund is formed as a limited partnership, which was permitted only after 2006 in China, the fund management entity refers to the general partners of the fund. If a VC fund i- t.ued as a corporation, the fund management entity refers to the management of thi. corporation.  

We define a VC firm's formation year  follows: (a) the year of the establishment for independent domestic VC fin -is: (b) the year of the first VC investment for non-independent domestic VC f -ms (e.g., those affiliated with existing business enterprises); (c) the year of the estaL!ishment for foreign VC firms with a specific focus on China or Asia if there is no crec fi  China focus; (d) the earlier of the year of the fund raising or the year of the Y'rst VC investment in China for the remaining foreign VC firms.  

We determint a VC firm's type based on the sources of all the VC funds raised as of the time of the VC firm's first round investment in an entrepreneurial company.7 If more than 50 percent of the VC firm's funds come from either government agencies or government-controlled business enterprises, the VC firm would be classified as a GVC. If more than 50 percent of the VC firm's funds come from domestic private sources, the VC firm would be classified as a PVC. If more than 50 percent of the VC firm's funds come from foreign sources, the VC firm would be classified as a FVC. If none of the above three types of fund sources contribute more than 50 percent of the VC firm's funds, the VC firm would be classified as a joint-venture (JVC).  

From CVSOURCE we identified a total of 1,336 VC firms that were founded before year 2012, the last available year when our project started. We exclude year 2012 because there were only 21 VC firms formed in 2012, prot ably due to a delay in CVSOURCE's data collection. Because there is no cle= cc distinction between VC firms and private equity firms in CVSOURCE, we de.ine a VC firm as one whose VC investments constitute more than 50 percent of the i: an's total equity investments as of the end of 2012. Among the 1,336 VC firms, ?13 are GVCs, 620 are PVCs, and 389 are FVCs. There are only 2 JVCs. In adc -tic .1, due to missing data, we cannot identify the type for 12 VC firms. In the subseyuent analyses, we exclude the 2 JVCs and the 12 unidentified VC firms. These re<trit ti ons result in a sample of 1,322 VC firms.  

Table 1 shows the istibution of the 1,322 VC firms. Panel A shows the distribution of the VC firn. oy founding year and type. It is clear that all three types of VC firm types experi. nced explosive growth over the past decade.  

Panel B of Table 1 shows the distribution of the 1,322 VC firms by province and type. The province where a VC firm is located is defined as follows: (a) the province of the VC firm's headquarters for domestic VC firms and foreign VC firms whose headquarters are located in mainland China (1026); and (b) the province of the mainland China office (172) or the province of the first VC investment if there is no mainland China office information (124), for foreign VC firms whose headquarters are located outside mainland China. It may not be too surprising that the VC firms are concentrated in relatively developed regions of China: Beijing, Shanghai, Guangdong, Jiangsu, and Zhejiang.  

Because the primary focus of the study is domestic VC firms (i.e., GVCs and PVCs), we exclude FVCs in the rest of the paper. We further divide GVCs into two types, GVC1, defined as GVCs that receive all their funding from government agencies or SOEs or both, and GVC2, defined as GVCs that receive son.? minority funding from private investors. We also divide PVCs into two types DvCi, defined as PVCs that receive all their funding from private investors, and P、C2, defined as PVCs that receive some minority funding from government agencies -ud/or SOEs. Consistent with the definitions of GVC and PVC, the definiticns of GVC1, GVC2, PVC1 and PVC2 are defined as of the time of each VC f.\*m's first round investment in an entrepreneurial company. GVC2 and PVC2 are mixt.? ownership VCs and our targets of interest.  

## 3. Research design  

Following prio izarch, we measure a VC firm's performance using two performance evaluati n metrics defined below: exit (successful versus unsuccessful) from a VC-financed company (exit) and the number of patent applications filed by a VCfinanced company during the two years since a VC firm's first round investment (patent_number). Because the data required to calculate the actual returns on VC firms' invested portfolio of entrepreneurial companies are usually unobservable, we follow prior research (Gompers and Lerner 2000; Brander et al. 2002; Hochberg et al. 2007; Sorensen 2007; Zarutskie 2007; Nahata 2008) by using exit as one proxy for VC firm performance.  

Phalippou and Gottschalg (2009) demonstrate a high positive correlation between successful exits and actual returns to venture capitalists, suggesting that exit should be a good proxy for VC firms’ performance.  

Cumming and Johan (2013) identify five common ways a VC firm may exit an investment in an entrepreneurial company: (i) initial Public Offering (IPO); (i) M&A, where both the entrepreneur and the VC firm sell their stake in the company to another company; (ii) secondary sale, where the VC firm sells its int.est but the entrepreneur does not sell his interest; (iv) management buyback, wher tu entrepreneur repurchases the stake held by the VC firm; and (v) liquidation of th. entrepreneurial company. While it is common in the U.S. VC literature to measure suie <ssful exits using IPOs and M&As only, VC firms in international VC marketr cfier exit successfully via secondary sales due to lack of access to the IPO mark t cr an underdeveloped M&A market. Therefore, our definition of successful exit inciides not only IPOs and M&As but also secondary sales, which is relatively freqr<nt ir. our sample as shown below.\* In addition, to the extent possible, we also iden. ify VC firms’ unsuccessful exits in the form of management buyback and liquidatio C". discussion with Chinese VC industry insiders suggests that management buybac, is typically viewed as a failure of VC investments. Because many VC firms may not have an incentive to voluntarily disclose liquidations of their funded entrepreneurial companies, we use a recently available company database from China's State Administration of Industry and Commerce (SAIC) to identify the majority of the liquidations in our sample.  

By definition, a primary objective of VC firms is to fund early-stage innovative but risky entrepreneurial companies. Hence, we also measure a VC firm's performance using a second proxy, patent_number, which reflects the degree of a VC-funded company's innovation. While not every innovation is patented and not every patent leads to successful economic activity, patenting and successful innovation are highly correlated and therefore patents are commonly used as a measure of innovation in the existing VC literature. To avoid potential confounding effects, we measure patent_number using only the patents filed within the first two years since a VC firm's first investment.

### 3.2. Patent applications  

We also examine whether the VC firm types differ in the number of patent applications filed by VC-funded companies during the first two years since a lead VC's initial round investment:  

patent_number VC ownership type control + e;  

See the Appendix for variable definitions. To reduce t'e influence of potential confounding effects, patent_number and other related pat-at .ariables introduced below are measured over the first two years after a lead VC fin n's initial round investment in an entrepreneurial company (Nanda and Rhodes-Krop z013). China has three types of patents: patents for invention, patents for u."'itv model, and patents for design. The protection period for invention paten.s ir twenty years while the protection period for utility model patents and design pau nts is only ten years, counted from the application date (http://english.sipo.gov.cn/> T.e approval of invention patents is more rigorous and takes longer than the othe. two types of patents. Our definition of patent_number includes the invention rate.ts and utility model patents filed over a two-year period since the lead VC firm's I'\*st round investment. Because invention patents take longer to be approved, patent_number includes both approved and unapproved invention patents but only approved patents for the utility model patents. We exclude design patents from patent_number because this classification type is unique to China and is often deemed low in innovation quality. Inferences are similar if design patents are included in the definition of patent_number.  

Patent applications are particularly interesting to study in China because the Chinese Government has been adopting a variety of proactive policies and incentives to encourage Chinese firms and VC funds to innovate, especially in the form of filing patent applications (Chan 2015; Chen 2015). The Chinese Government even made an explicit call for local Chinese firms to apply for two million patents by 2015 (The Economist 2014). Being government-controlled, GVCs are expected to be more responsive to the Chinese Government's order. However, due to conflicting instiutional forces discussed in the Introduction, it is an open question whether GVC ran. outperform non-GVCs in patent filings.  

There is anecdotal evidence suggesting th.' some Chinese firms may have resorted to filing many lower quality patent ${\mathrm{\Delta}}^{\mathrm{\Delta}}\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{\mathbf{i}}}^{\mathrm{\Delta}}$ ic.tions such as utility model patents and design patents in response to the Ch. es : Government's order (The Economist 2014). Hence, we consider three alternat.e definitions of patent performance measures to mitigate the potential noises as-oci at ed with patent_number. To the extent that a firm's main objective of filing a pa. \*nt application is to satisfy the Chinese Government's order, we expect the firm to bav. 'ess incentive to pay the required annual maintenance fee to keep the patent activt in the years subsequent to the initial patent application. Hence, we use active_patent_number as an alternative definition of patent performance, which includes only the invention and utility model patents still active as of April 2014, the date when we collected the patent data. Recognizing that the approval process for invention patents is more rigorous and takes longer, firms whose main objective of filing a patent application is to satisfy the Chinese Government's order should be less likely to submit invention patents. Hence, we also use the number of invention patent applications (invent_patent_number) as another alternative innovation performance measure. Finally, if a firm's main objective of filing a patent application is to satisfy the Chinese Government's order, the quality of the patents filed by such firms is likely to be lower. We use patent_citation as a proxy for the quality of filed patent applications. Because the Google Patent Citations database excludes design patents, the least important type, our definition of patent_citation includes invention patents and utility model patents only.

These results  suggest  that   the entrepreneurial companies funded by PVCs outperform those funded by GVCs in terms of total number of patent applications. This evidence implies that the higher number of total patent applications for PVCs is not due to the submission of lower quality patent applications ' / PVCs.  

With regard to the control variables in 'no lel (2), several of them are significant and consistent with our predictions. M.ost noteworthy is the significantly positive coefficient on priorpatent, suggestin.g the persistence of corporate innovation success. The coefficient on synsize is <'so cgnificantly positive in the first three regressions, suggesting the importance o.: VC syndicate in the innovation performance of VC firmsfunded entrepreneurial cc.panies. The coefficient on enlocal_invpro is significantly positive in all the i. gressions, suggesting that a region's investor protection have a positive impact on the region's VC-funded companies′ innovation output.  

## 5. The relative performance of mixed ownership VCs  

We next examine the performance of mixed ownership VCs by comparing the performance of GVC1 versus GVC2 and PVC1 versus PVC2.  

### 5.1. Regression results for model (1)  

Panel A of Table 4 provides the descriptive statistics on the distribution of the VC-funded entrepreneurial companies across the four VC firm types. There are sufficient number of observations for each VC firm type, but GVC1 has the largest number of financed entrepreneurial companies. If one defines GVC1, GVC2, and PVC2 as government-sponsored VC firms, the number of entrepreneurial companies funded by government-sponsored VC firms would constitute approximateiy $72\%$ of all VC-funded companies in our sample. This finding is different from th. 1.s. VC industry, suggesting the significant influence of the Chinese government-lin.'ed entities in the development of China's VC industry.  

Panel B shows the regression results oi 'no lel (1) for the four VC firm types. The key variables of interest are gvcl, gv 2, .nd pvcl. The definitions of gvcl, gvc2, pvcl, and pvc2 are defined similarly to tha\* of gvc above. We use pvc2 as our benchmark and therefore the coefficient on $p^{\ldots}2$ ( suppressed in the multinomial logit model. With regard to the performance coniparison for GVC1 versus GVC2, we find that the coefficient  on  gvcl ic $\operatorname{S1}_{\boldsymbol{\mathsf{E}}}\mathbf{r}$ ficantly more negative than the coefficient on gvc2 for successful exits, sugg \~sting that introducing minority private investors helps improve the odds of GVCs’ successful exits. On the other hand, the coefficient on gvcl is also significantly more negative than the coefficient on $g\nu c{2}$ for unsuccessful exits, suggesting that introducing minority private investors also increases the variance of GVCs' performance. However, Panel A of Table 2 shows that unsuccessful exits still represent only the minority of all exits, and therefore we conclude from the above overall regression results that introducing minority private investors helps improve the performance of GvCs.  

Despite the better performance of GVC2 relative to GVC1, it is still important to note that GVC2s still underperform PVCs. Specifically, the coefficient on gvc2 is significantly negative for successful exits. In addition, the coefficient on gvc2 is significantly more negative than the coefficient on pvcl for successful exits.  

With regard to the performance comparison for PVC1 v. rsus PVC2, we find that the coefficient pvcl is not significant for both successf! eaits and unsuccessful exits. Hence, we find no evidence that introducing mint.ity government investors helps improve the performance of PVCs. This finding is in cesting because it is different from the results for GVC1 versus GVC2.  

### 5.2. Regression results for model (2)  

Panel C of Table 4 shov# tl α egression results of model (2) for the four VC firm types. With regard to the pe. formiance comparison for GVC1 versus GVC2, we find that the coefficient on $g\nu c^{\prime}\lambda\iota$ lways more negative than the coefficient on gvc2 in the regressions of paten_ number, active_patent_nuber, and invent_patent_number but they are not significantly different from each other. Overall, these results provide at best very weak evidence that introducing minority private investors helps improve the innovation productivity of GVCs.  

With regard to the performance comparison for PVC1 versus PVC2, we find that the coefficient on pvcl is insignificant in all the patent models except for invent_patent_number. Hence, consistent with the regression results in section 5.1, there is litle evidence that introducing minority government investors helps improve the innovation productivity of PVCs.  

### 5.3. Summary  

Overall, the regression results in section 5.1 and 5.2 portray a consistent picture with regard to the role of mixed ownership. First, introducing minority private investors helps improve the performance of GVCs. Second, there is no vidence that introducing minority government investors helps improve the performncs sf PVCs. The asymmetry of the results for GVCs and PVCs is interesting and pi vides relevant information to the ongoing debate on the reform of Chinese SOEs in gen, cal.  

## 6. Further analyses  

We perform several additioral tests to assess the robustness of our primary regression results in sections 4 ^\~d  

### 6.1. First round VC invsu.'At amount  

Prior researci. suggests that larger VC investments are associated with better entrepreneurial company quality (Gompers 1995; Makela and Maula 2006). Since VC firms’ total first round investment amount is missing for a significant number of our sample entrepreneurial companies, we exclude this variable from the regression tables 2- 4. As a robustness check, we now include the total first round VC investment (vc investment amount) as a control variable in model (1) and report the results in Panel A of Table 5. Even though the sample size drops substantially, the inferences from Panel A of  

Table 5 are almost identical to those from Tables 2-4.14 One noticeable exception is that the significant results for gvcl vs. gvc2 for unsuccessful exits in Table 4 are no longer significant in Table 5.  

### 6.2. VC firm's investment horizon  

While we believe that the hazard model specification in Tables 2 and 4 is preferred due to the right censoring of VC firm exit, one count argue that different VC firms have different fixed holding periods and therefore th\~ s<cessful and unsuccessful exit rates could be deflated for VC firms with longer colding periods.1 To address this concern, we also follow Brander et al. (2015) by es"cinating model (1) using only one observation per entrepreneurial company. exit_ on lition is measured as before but all the other control variables are measured &- th ? time of the lead VC's initial investment. The results of this alternative model (i) are shown in Panel B of Table 5. None of our inferences in Tables 2 and 4 are ig. ificantly altered.  

### 6.3. Foreign minority invest rs  

Our definitio. \~ of GVC2 and PVC2 may contain minority ownership by foreign investors. To rule out the possibility that our results could be contaminated by the inclusion of such foreign ownership, we also remove 154 entrepreneurial companies that are funded by GVC2 with foreign minority investor ownership and 21 entrepreneurial companies that are funded by PVC2 with foreign minority investor ownership. The results are reported in Table 6. None of our inferences are affected.  

### 6.4. Endogeneity of VC ownership types  

One of the key unresolved challenges in assessing the causal impact of ownership structure on firm performance is the endogeneity of ownership structure (Himmelberg et al. 1999). Prior research shows that it is difficult to deve'op credible exogenous instruments for ownership structure (Coles et al. 2012). O# s-dy is no exception to this challenge. Specifically, the ownership structure of Vc firms could be endogenous. For example, GVCs could be more prevalent in pi、 vinces with weaker institutional environments and therefore GVCs tend to pe1?rr poorly. In addition, the types of VCfunded entrepreneurial companies cot 4 F systematically different for GVCs and PVCs due to self selection. For example, GvCs may prefer to invest in early stage and therefore riskier entrepreneurial companj\~\~ 1  ling to lower performance.  

We attempt to addre s the endogeneity challenge in several ways. First, to the extent possible, we controi for the observable VC firm characteristics and entrepreneurial company characteris.\*cs (see section 3), mitigating the concern that the performance differences across the VC ownership types are due to differences in the characteristics of VC firms or VC-financed entrepreneurial companies.  

Second,  we check whether the geographic distributions are systematically different for the GVCs and PVCs. As shown in Panel B of Table 1, the majority of both GVCs and PVCs are located in the five most developed provinces (i.e., Beijing, Shanghai, Guangdong, Zhejiang, Jiangsu), but the percentage is significantly higher for  

PVCs than for GVCs ( $64.22\%$ for GVCs and $82.74\%$ for PVCs and $\chi^{2}\mathrm{~p~}$ value ${\it\Omega}=0.000,$ Untabulated statistics also show that the percentage of VCs located in the five most developed provinces is $56.90\%$ for GVC1, $79.25\%$ for GVC2, $83.17\%$ for PVC1, and $80\%$ for PVC2. The difference is significantly different for GVC1 versus GVC2 $(\mathbb{X}^{2}\mathrm{~p~}$ value ${:=}0.005\$ ） but not significant for PVC1 versus PVC2 $(\chi^{2}$ p value=0.627). These descriptive statistics suggest that GVCs tend to be located in provinces with weaker institutional environments, which could explain the weaker pt.-formance of GVCs. To address this concern, we have already controlled for en'ru'_cnvpro, local_talent, and local_R&D in all relevant tables. To more effectively csntrol for location-related omitted variables, we further include an entrepreneurial $\mathrm{{co}\it{m}_{\mathrm{{t}}}}$ any's province fixed effects in the regressions of Table 4 so that any location sre iic fixed effects would be fully controlled for. As shown in Table 7, we find the sar.e inferences as in Table 4. In addition, we run the tests in Tables 2-4 by limiting cur sample to the five provinces with the most VC firms. As shown in Table 8, we finc cualitatively similar inferences.  

Finally, we use a oropensity score matching approach to deal with the endogeneity concern $\mathbf{e^{+}V\Sigma^{\widehat{\mathbf{\Gamma}}}}$ Jwnership types. Specifically, we first obtain the propensity scores for each entre,reneurial company observation in the year of the lead VC's initial investment by regressing gvc on all the relevant explanatory variables of models (1) and (2) in the year of the lead VC's initial investment. The list of the explanatory variables include early, priorpatent, priorcitation, vc_lp, synsize, vc_exp, vc_repu, vc_network, exit_condition enlocal_invpro, local_talent, local_R&D Industry and Initial vc investment year. Second, we match with replacement each $g\nu c{=}1$ observation with a $g\nu c{=}0$ observation with the closest propensity score. We require the difference of the matched pair's propensity scores to be less than $1\%$ . We successfully obtained 970 matched pairs of GVCs and non-GVCs. Finally, we repeat our primary regression results in Tables 2-4 using these matched pairs. As shown in Table 9, we obtain similar inferences for both performance measures.  

## 7. Conclusion  

We examine the impact of mixed ownership on the per'ormance of Chinese VC firms. Broadly speaking, we can divide all domestic Chi-st 'C firms into two types, GVCs and PVCs. GVCs are VC firms that receive ti.? majority of their funding from either government agencies or government-controllec 'usiness enterprises or both. PVCs are VC firms that receive the majority of their nd ing from domestic private sources. We can further divide GVCs into two tyf \*s, GVC1, defined as GVCs that receive all their funding from government agencies t SOEs or both, and GVC2, defined as GVCs that receive some minority funding fror yrivate investors. We can also divide PVCs into two types, PVC1, defined as PV <s tuat receive all their funding from private investors, and PVC2, defined as PVCe ti ?7 receive some minority funding from government agencies and/or SOEs. GVC2 . na PVC2 are mixed ownership VC firms.  

We measure a VC firm's performance using both the VC firm's successful/unsuccessful exit from its invested entrepreneurial companies and the quantity of patent applications filed during the two years since the first round VC investment.  

Consistent with existing research on the performance of SOEs versus non-SOEs, we find that GVCs as a whole significantly underperform PVCs for both performance metrics. More importantly, however, we find that GVC2 helps improve the performance of GVCs. Specifically, we find that GVC2s outperform GVC1s for successful exits, suggesting that introducing minority private investors to GVCs helps improve the performance of GVCs. On the other hand, we find no evidence that PVC1s differ from PVC2s in performance for both performance metrics, suggesting that introducing minority government investors to PVCs fails to improve the performance of PVCs.  

The findings of our study should be of interest to the ongoing debate on the costs and benefits of introducing mixed ownership in the VC industiy development. This issue is particularly relevant in many emerging countries where che YC industry is nascent and therefore the government often plays a bigger role in de eloping the VC industry.  

Prior research shows that VC firms contrib.'< to the financial performance of entrepreneurial companies in two important α \* vs (i) identify promising entrepreneurial companies for investment (i.e., selec.or ability); and (ii) monitor the performance of invested entrepreneurial companies (i.e., monitoring ability). In this study we examine the overall financial performarre (f VC firms with differential government ownership. Due to data limitations, we 'on't attempt to distinguish VC firms’ selection ability from their monitoring abilitv w' 'eave this unresolved issue to future research.  

We have als implicitly assumed that all  VC firms care about financial performance. While it is reasonable to assume that PVCs care about the ultimate financial performance of their invested entrepreneurial companies. This assumption may not hold for GVCs because GVCs may have not only financial but also non-financial objectives. As a result, using financial performance indicators to judge the success of GVCs may not be appropriate. Unfortunately, it is difficult to obtain data on the non-financial performance goals and indicators of GVCs. We leave this unresolved issue to future research.
